comments.commentBody: This is absolutely true.  The real question is why we feel we have to visit Aunt Mildred three times a year instead of once every two years, which we were both quite thrilled with at the time.  One might ask the same thing about being in contact with everyone one has ever met in one's life all year long rather than those one feels close to, just through (rather long and thoughtful) messages written in Christmas or other holiday cards, plus the occasional phone call during the year.  Once upon a time, new inventions made it easier for us to do things we already did, like wash clothes and climb stairs.  Now, they make things faster, but not necessarily easier and certainly not always more pleasant.  They seem to result in less free time rather than more.  I think the personal computer was a great invention, but it is also clear that one result (intentional?) was that it would make it possible for those who control various bits of our lives to make us do more for them, not less.  Ditto the cell phone and its spinoffs.  The jumbo jet and deregulation came into being, without considering anything but one of their consequences, the cheaper ticket.  We make changes and never think of the societal results beforehand.

Hey Alan
By any chance do you work for an airline?
No need to stretch back to 1974; I started flying a lot in the 1990's and the experience has deteriorated at breakneck speed since then.

Air travel has been one of those "watch what you ask for" situations. Sure things were better "back in the good old days", such as 1974. But prices were regulated, with the minimum price of a New York to LA flight costing $1442 in inflation adjusted 2013 dollars. If you are willing to pay the equivalent of the 1974 fare NOW, you will get an even better air travel experience (business or First Class) as well as a far safer flight.

It is incredibly unrealistic to expect the 1974 flying experience for the equivalent of 1/5 of the price.

Yup! I agree with everything Frank Bruni writes here. I fly only when there is no other option. So I very seldom fly. I worry about global warming, and it isn't very pleasant anyway to fly..as Frank points out, getting to the airport isn't much fun either. For those that must fly, I am sorry for them. But it is quick, and with no decent high speed rail, Americans don't have options. As I've said repeatedly, our system in the US is controlled by oil and gas. Anything that promotes burning it gets a pass. We need an "attitude adjustment" as the song goes, about how we use energy, particularly fossil fuels.
Doing right in the NFL? It is all about the money. When Goodell hurts the bottom line, only then will he go.
The more that the people who attend these games know about the serious risks of brain injury for the players, the more that football arenas have become Colosseums, and football the public spectacle.

We kill more people every month in this country, by denying them health care, than died that day in that place. And we are the only first world nation that does so. We now employ more people looking through your underwear in airports than we have studying the oceans.
Next time you are in a TSA screening line ask the screener if they caught any terrorists today? If they say no, ask- this week? This month? Last year? Ever? Well if not you someone here has, right?
You got it right about the ridiculous pits. What a waste of money and space.

Well, that is NY's "recognized form," precisely. It has its interest, its monstrous beauty. And it makes you want to run out of these dry spaces into its other more human scale spaces full of life and people.

In reviewing the design of a building, some consideration should be made for the purpose of the building.  Some buildings are constructed to display wealth, to create construction jobs, or to fill empty space.  China has been very successful at all three.  European cathedrals were also successful at consuming money and filling space, but religiously, they made a bold statement on 12 and 13th C. paupers.  People die all the time, 10 times as many Americans on highways every year than in the World Trade Center Towers, just once.  But the need to elevate these victims above all others is  very apparent in the two grotesque pits with a power plant dedicated to circulating water and in the new building.  The World Trade towers that stacked thousands of people for whatever purpose were the most utilitarian buildings known this side of Russian apartment blocks.  The Freedom tower will have offices that are basically identical and maybe a little less intimidating to passers-by.  Funny how a city on the Aegean Sea can have every building a cube covered in white stucco with an identical tile roof and look so well integrated and perform so well when in NYC every building is isolated from its surroundings and indigenous materials, competing for attention rather than helping to create a cohesive and recognizable form.

It could be worse..........there could be Lions in the Coliseum.

Come to think of it, aren't there some in Detroit?

What makes you say that economic inequality is caused by racism?  I would say that economic inequality is caused by unequal opportunity and unequal drive and ability.  I believe that there is currently a somewhat equal playing field in much of the US, so much of economic inequality is now determined by individual ability and choices.

JEG, unequal opportunity you are correct about. Your assertion that there IS an equal playing field is not correct. This is a favorite of the successful on the right..a self justification of wanting things to continue as they are, and at the best, demonstrating a lack of empathy and ignorance of circumstances of the down trodden. A little humility is in order here…birth is the luck of the draw. Being born in the USA is maybe a happier situation than being born a child forced into fighting in Africa for instance. I "get" that working hard is a good idea. I've done it myself. But until you've walked a mile in another's shoes, it's probably best to withhold your judgement of them, as I give you the benefit of the doubt. Unequal opportunity defines what is at the heart of racism. It is "power over" by one group over another.
If economic opportunity is "somewhat equal" and Black people have a lesser slice of the pie, then "unequal drive and ability" in the context of this argument means "Black people are lazy and stupid."

Economic inequality is the biggest problem Americans face. Blacks are the least wealthy. This is caused by racism. Until people become more enlightened and develop some empathy for others, it seems to be a long slog ahead for social justice.

Here's what's wrong with your comment - "the government hasn't built rail extentions to the airports." Why is this the job of goverment? And that's coming from a liberal democrat!

And please, let's not talk about broadband speed being laughable. The government of the territorially large (sarcasm) country of Belgium planned on completing its 3G expansion by the end of 2014, after almost the entire USA is covered by 4G/LTE.

America is the land of All for One and none for all. Because of this we have full spectrum breakdown of public infrastructure and third-rate transportation systems. Our healthcare stinks. Utilities and broadband are laughable. It's dog eat dog at work and Ebola and ISIS on the news at home. And at the end of the day we can't even sleep well, as daily life spikes cortisol and adrenaline to the level of constant leopard attack. It's truly a miserable state of being.

After all that: now let's fly.

The government hasn't built rail extentions to the airports. So we drive. This usually takes awhile, as the roads are often traffic snarled and pothole ridden. They were designed and built in the 1950s. Following the lemming line of brake lights and stop-and-go, we arrive at departures. But not really. There's mountains to climb and indignities to suffer before we actually depart.

Once inside the terminal, we're all suspected terrorists. Common folks wait in long lines and are forced to partially disrobe. We get body scanned. Some of us are physically molested. After baring our souls to the TSA, clothes go back on and we wait to board. Oftentimes, this gate-waiting goes on awhile. Eventually, mercifully, finally, we stomp down the ramp into the sardine can. Welcome aboard!

Let the battle begin.

After all the stress inducing misery that preceeds our flight, is it really any wonder we behave like selfish jerks once we're crammed inside a flying can?

We were able to get a bottle of the 2009 Muga ($27.99) at our provincial liquor store as well as a bottle of the 2008 Marqués de Murrietta ($29.99). We opened both bottles to breathe a bit while we had a glass of Basa Verdejo. When we sat down to appetizers we first tried the Murrietta. It had a lovely soft vanilla nose and the taste had muted oak, pepper, and maybe tobacco. Definitely some spice and a smooth finish. The Muga was more acidic with more tannin and some spice. It seemed less subtle than the Murrietta.

We decided to leave the Muga to breathe a bit longer to see if it opened up a bit more and enjoyed the Murrietta with our appetizer. Some 30 minutes later we got back to the Muga. It was a bit more open and a bit less tannic than when we started but we all agreed that we preferred the Murrietta. Over all we felt that both wines were worth the price we paid and the Murrietta a definite 'buy again'.
An incontinent, 70 pound pig: not a bad emblem for airline economy operations these days!

Carolyn, your comment connects well with the top two in this recommended list. You three are all telling readers and the US - if the US would listen - that there are fundamental subjects that must be tackled, far more fundamental than much of what we are offered day after day.

How can we get NYT columnists to focus on the fundamental instead of only the daily incident? I have been trying with Charles Blow for a long time without success. Professor Dorothy Roberts tried for a long time starting at least two years ago. She a professional and I a lay person wanted the same thing, to deal with something very fundamental. That thing was that in the Times classification by race is not only accepted but former Times columnist Nicholas Wade could say over and over again, there is, for example, a genetic basis for "black" behaviors (plural). We could not get the Times and still cannot get the Times to consider other views.

See CK's very fine comment today. I will be copying it and sending it to my Verified Inner Circle including you. Even better, reply to CK, who, I am guessing, is black. If he or she is then I have a second black soul friend at the Times, where blackmamba is my first. Blackmamba, CK, and I think alike on this subject, apparently in isolation from most commenters and all columnists.
Larry

Racism exists among us, but it is exacerbated by how drastically our country has been militarized in the past thirty years, since Reagan. Militarized police dressed up in military uniforms and helmets, armed to the teeth, is not what we need in this country. A government that surveils its citizens is just plain outrageous, yet the whole Patriot Act lives on. Racism becomes even more lethal when it is backed up by the powerful elite with riot gear and pepper spray. These methods are an assault on one's human rights. Matter of fact, the US has not gotten a good report from the United Nations lately.

Sperring appears to be self-treating an underlying mood disorder -- quite possibly chronic depression -- with these highly addictive, dangerous "meds." If she experiences life without a drug high as inherently, unbearably painful, she will feel drawn again and again to use drugs that may kill her. If she suffers from depression, she should explore, seek to understand, and fight it. Many people with lifelong depression simply don't understand there  are other ways of feeling, and that change is possible.
I know white men who got 16 years for weed and have heard of black males who got 2 weeks for murder or rape.  These double standards go both ways.
Thank you. This hits it on the nail.

An additional factor, not yet mentioned, is that the previously excellent public universities have become a poor shadow of their worth to prior generations, in affordability, capacity, and quality.

This is due to state governments slashing their funding to state universities-- in some cases, plummeting from 90% of the cost of attendance covered by the state in prior generations, to 5% now. (And this, I believe, results from the extraordinarily short-sighted view that higher education is a private good, rather than a benefit to society and our economy.)

Results: tuition is much higher; many can no longer select students without regard for their ability to pay; out-of-state and foreign applicants are sought after for their ability to pay higher tuition;and waiting lists for required courses are so long that some full-time students who do everything right still can't graduate in 4 years, because they can't get into required courses. Some can't even complete their desired major for this reason.(California state colleges reported a wait list of 5,000 students for some required courses.)

This is in addition to the other reasons for fewer slots mentioned elsewhere in these comments.

I do advise students that there are many colleges where they can get an excellent education. I encourage them to find schools for which they are a good qualitative match.

But fewer colleges meet financial need, beyond the "famous few". Putting aside snobbery,that is the best reason to aim for them.

"but she's going to need her daughter's help, and the help of anyone else still willing to associate with her"
I 100% disagree with this statement. Her daughter is not here to help her mother. Ms. sperring's daughter is not here to give moral, spiritual, or physical support in anyway to her Mother. She in no way has to be a 'grownup' in this situation. Her father needs to put as much distance as he can from daughter and mother. Ms. Sperring's daughter needs to go to school, look forward to her life, think about college, have fun with her friends and try to forget all this mess. Her Mother is going to be toxic for a very long time. The level of toxicity in her moms brain is going to take years to overcome, and during that time she will not be capable of being a mother or anything much else. It will a long climb back, but it is up to her and her alone. Tough yes, but realistic. No one on this planet can experience truth for another human being. Some people need to really, really experience the "dark night of the soul", that 3:00 in the morning when you know that when the sun comes up it is time for a very big change, You can ask for professional help and can get it in this country. She can live in a shelter for Women. If I was her husband I would not let my daughter anywhere near her.

it is hard to understand why this society would allow  those thugs to rake in big bucks who promote this kind of culture.  they are rich and famous, and can afford the drug/rehab cycle. but average families would be totally ruined if one member becomes addicted.

This is MRS.  And, if this person really cleaned up, you may not be able to be married to him any more either.  His sincerity is only there when he needs some support from you.  It goes away when he gets his satisfaction.  I, too, was married to a very selfish, self-centered alcoholic who became abusive when I set parameters about what I would no longer accept.  Funny thing how he told everyone I was the "bad guy" in the relationship and that was why he dumped me.  My life's been a whole lot better without him but I was too Catholic 28 years ago to divorce.  He did me a favor in the end.  State of Ohio made him get some responsibility and I had the privilege of enforcing it through the court system.  He's now eligible for early retirement, but I doubt he has a good enough stipend to retire before age 70.  He chose low wage employment instead of using the college degree I sacrificed working to pay for him to go to school full time without working,  so he has to make his decisions based on what Social Security will now award him.  And, he knows he can never come back to me or most of his family because of what he has done.  Oh, well.

I was involved with a man, a decent handsome man, but he was an alcoholic for years, interspersed with xanax, vicodan, and pot.  I did not know this when I met him.  Then he started losing jobs and lying to cover his tracks.  His parents have helped him; I helped him always believing things would change.  They have not.  I believe he has been in rehab 8 times.  I still care for him because he really is a "good sweet sincere person," but I can't do it anymore.  Time to move on. Chronic relapsing addicts, regardless the substance, are emtionally draining.  Some do get better, but the relapse rate is very high and one substance is exchanged for another.  I would recommend to never get involved with an addict who did not have  several consecutive years of sobriety because you cannot change anything, and it's a constant heartache and money suck.

Why is it the fault of society and not the individual for engaging in criminal behavior?   We made a choice sometime ago in our society when we decided not to hold people accountable for their actions.  Blame everyone and everything else in society for their problems, choices, and bad decisions.  There is so much help out their for the unfortunates, paid for by the rest of us.  Who, when we saw our families ripped apart by drugs, or lost a partner, or lost a loved one, saw someone we love abused etc., etc., did not decide to do drugs or commit crimes to make ourselves feel better, no, we just kept working, kept helping others, kept making decent choices, not perfect, but decent.  Enough.  Everyone has a back story.  It is a matter of character often times, and unfortunately that is sadly lacking in our society.  I take no blame for this individuals personal choices.  I do not feel sad for her.  It annoys me that she has so much to be grateful for and chooses to ruin herself and her family. Or did society put the needle in her arm?

It works. I moved away to another state and have had no contact with any of the people I associated with through school years. I hear from others that many OD'ed and others are just a waste of oxygen. Few made it out without prison time as well. You have to take care of you. Who else will?

Laurie sperring unfortunately will probably never change. her daughter should end contact and begin a new life as harsh as it sounds. remember the good times if there were any and use the bad example for guidance, the other way
You're right. She doesn't deserve any sympathy.I mean everyone knows beating addiction is a piece of cake.

Life is hard.  But when everyone around you gives you chance after chance; when you endanger the wellbeing of your children, and children for whom you have accepted a  parental role; when  you betray everyone to whom you owe loyalty, honesty and devotion--yeah--I'd say you used up whatever sympathy you might have been entitled to.

It's not about treatment options, or their lack.

It's about caring enough about the people you are supposed to be responsible for. When you believe their needs are more important than yours, you do what is necessary to achieve enough wellness in yourself to be the good parent, the good partner.

Without that inner desire, no treatment will bring lasting results.

Ms. Sperring betrayed her child, her stepchildren, her husband, and the son of the cool addict she fancies. She was given more chances than many other people ever get, and she blew them again and again. Why has she been profiled here with relative sympathy?

To liken coffee with heroin is pretty silly. Heroin is a one-way street to degradation and death. The number of users who come out the other end in something like one piece is minuscule. And it destroys not only the user, but poisons everyone it touches. Loved ones are manipulated, lied to, stolen from - anything to get that next high. People turn to heroin when they have given up. It is close to literally selling one's soul to the devil: you can have me as long as you make me feel really good for a while first. Yes, many of us are "addicted" to coffee or shopping or sugar or sex or whatever - but these are a whole other level of compulsion. If anyone has ever wrecked their life to drink coffee it would be news to me.

I have taken the same dose of vicodin for 7   years without incident. I'm not bothering anyone and am highly functional professiinal. However, because of "there's a crisis let's fix-it" of our otherwise useless government - here FDA- vicodin got moved to schedule II which makes it harder to get for legitimate users and solves nothing as pill users can easily move to heroin. Oh, and to show what this is all about, at the time FDA bounced vicodin to Sched II it approved a type of vicodin- pure hydrocodone absent the tylenol! Like oxycontin, the perfect drug for a junkie. But because it is under patent,.it gets approved. Complete corruption & absurdity.

We live in a world of addiction, sadly. Even more sad is that many of the addicts do it legally and with a prescription. (And the dealers legally advertise and give it away to physicians). But those folks need those drugs because they're 'sick'.

Coffee anyone?

For what it's worth, bus travel is becoming the latest variant of chic between Washington, DC and NYC.  I just tried it for $54 round trip (Tripper Bus) and the comfort level was equivalent to airline economy class.

I do wish there were good alternatives to flying when it comes to mass transportation. I was going to a relative's wedding in New Orleans but my truck's transmission was iffy. I looked up the prices of Amtrak travel from Oklahoma City to New Orleans and was surprised to see that it was almost five hundred dollars and took two days to get to New Orleans. Two days when it it's about ten hours by car. Why so long and expensive? Because the train leaves OKC and goes to Chicago, the opposite direction from New Orleans. Once you're in Chicago, you get to travel back across two-thirds of the country to New Orleans. I'd ride the train if it was fast and went to where you want to go. Why can't we have good train service to all of America?
Best comment. There are not 113 elite colleges and no one would consider any school below around 30th place to be the equivalent of Harvard or Stanford.

Get real. Have you ever been around people high on crack, smack or meth? They are a danger to themselves, a danger to others - especially if they get behind the wheel of a car - and incapable of raising a family. Who is going to take care of their kids? Are you willing to share the road with people high on heroin? Unless you give access to everyone, even minors, there will still be a black market. But if you give universal access, usage will grow.

I am completely in favor of decriminalizing drugs but outright legalization will be a disaster. Many countries have tried some form of legalization and all have regretted it. The problems of containment, health of the users, child welfare, and public safety all need to be solved with any scheme that gives access to drugs.

Problem is, that hard drugs like heroin and crack are costly and addicts keep upping their usage. So they don't just quietly get high in the privacy of their homes. They steal from the rest of us. They drive cars and get in accidents, and injure other people.

They don't work -- they can't, because they are high most of the time -- so they go on welfare and food stamps, and we have to support them.

They also destroy the lives of their children, so WE (the rest of society) have to pay for and raise THEIR children. They don't pay taxes (cuz they don't work), so when they go to the ER with an overdose (which is a certainty), WE (the rest of society) have to pay for their huge medical bills, including costly rehab (which mostly does not work) and incarceration (which protects us from them, but does nothing to cure addiction).

I am permanently disabled and missing a few external body parts. Yet---I can find NO WAY to actually GET any form of "aid" or "assistence" such as food stamps oir disability. I do not know HOW or WHY any "Welfare" agency would give these people this when I--as a sober and law abiding person who DID work when I was ABLE to--can get NOTHING.

I really wish there was a clear cut break down of WHO is getting AID when they are addicted. Because I see a lot of these comments and I have to wonder if this is really TRUE or Urban LEgend.

Does the DEA pay the NYTimes to write these horror stories?  Legalize drugs, already.  People will use drugs whether it's legal or not.  If addicts want to kill themselves with drugs, so what?  It's more Social Security for the rest of us.  Many states have right-to-die laws.  How is decriminalizing drug use any different?  Keeping drugs illegal profits only lawyers, judges, cops, prison guards, rehab clinics, halfway houses, doctors, hospitals, drug companies, etc. but disenfranchises the rest of us.  It's the main reason many of us visit a doctor - to renew our prescription - and why our health care system is bankrupting us.  Like alcohol Prohibition in the 1930s when the widespread and open consumption of alcohol made a mockery of civil society, stiff drugs penalties are bankrupting our states where prisons are so filled to capacity we let loose murderers.  Drug profits fund narco-states and terrorist organizations and inadvertently our military-industrial/big pharma-medical complex.  And our War on Drugs undermines our freedoms as we descend ever more into a police state.  Enough already.  Drug prohibition has had a long list of unintended consequences.
